questions.text: A patient with acute coalescent mastoiditis undergoes cortical mastoidectomy. Which of the following is used as a surgical landmark to locate the mastoid antrum?
questions.solution: Macewen’s (suprameatal) triangle is used as a surgical landmark to locate the mastoid antrum. In an adult, the antrum lies 12–15 mm from the surface. This triangle is also the site of tenderness in acute mastoiditis.

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be seen in a patient with nasopharyngeal angiofibroma?
questions.solution:
Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma presents with rhinolalia clausa (hyponasal speech), not rhinolalia aperta (hypernasal speech).

The patients present with progressive nasal obstruction and hyponasal speech due to mass in the postnasal space. Profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis is the most common presentation. The patients may be markedly anemic due to repeated blood loss.

Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion occur due to obstruction of the eustachian tube.

It can spread to the orbit giving rise to proptosis and broadening of the nasal bridge, giving rise to frog face deformity. Other features include swelling of the cheek and cranial nerve palsies (II, III, IV, and VI).

questions.text: A worried mother brings her febrile infant to the ER. He is crying incessantly and clutching his ear. He had the following finding on otoscopy. What is the most likely organism implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the image showing congested tympanic membrane with purulent effusion and absent cone of light is suggestive of acute suppurative otitis media. The most likely organism implicated is Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Organisms causing ASOM in infants and young children:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae 
  • Moraxella catarrhalis 
  • Streptococcus pyogenes
  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Related Pearl: Microbiology of the middle ear

 
ASOM
CSOM
Aerobic organisms
Streptococcus pneumoniae (30%)
 
H. influenzae (20%)
 
M. catarrhalis (12%)
 
Strep. pyogenes
 
Staph. aureus
 
Pseudomonas aeruginosa
Mixed growth
(Most common)
 
Pseudomonas aeruginosa
 
Proteus
 
E. coli
 
Staph. aureus
 
Anaerobic organisms
---
Bacteriodes fragilis
 
Anaerobic Streptococci

questions.text: An ENT surgeon has difficulty locating the mastoid antrum due to the presence of Korner's septum. Which of the following sutures is persistent in this case?
questions.solution:
The persistence of the petrosquamous suture is called Korner’s septum and it is responsible for the difficulty in locating the mastoid antrum and the deeper cells. 

Korner’s septum separates superficial squamosal cells from the deep petrosal cells.

Incomplete removal of disease at mastoidectomy can occur if Korner’s septum is not identified. Mastoid antrum cannot be reached unless the Korner’s septum has been removed.

Below is an image showing Korner's septum -

questions.text: Which of the following is an intrinsic membrane of the larynx?
questions.solution:
The cricothyroid membrane is an intrinsic membrane of the larynx as it connects laryngeal structures to each other.

Extrinsic membranes and ligaments connect laryngeal structures with surrounding structures outside the laryngeal framework like the trachea or hyoid. These are:

  • Cricotracheal membrane
  • Thyrohyoid membrane
  • Hyoepiglottic ligament.

Intrinsic membranes and ligaments connect laryngeal structures with each other. These are:

  • Cricovocal membrane
  • Quadrangular membrane
  • Cricothyroid ligament
  • Thyroepiglottic ligament.

questions.text: You have a patient with maxillary sinus carcinoma. Which of the following lymph nodes will be most commonly involved?
questions.solution:
The submandibular and jugulodigastric nodes are the most commonly involved in maxillary sinus carcinoma.

Maxillary and ethmoid sinus drain primarily into retropharyngeal nodes but, these nodes are inaccessible for palpation.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy diagnosed with adenoid hypertrophy has undergone an adenoidectomy procedure. Two weeks following the procedure, he developed Grisel syndrome. What is the reason for this condition?
questions.solution:
Grisel syndrome involves paraspinal muscle spasm that occurs post adenoidectomy.

Grisel syndrome refers to non-traumatic atlantoaxial joint subluxation. The patient complains of neck pain and develops torticollis. It is mostly due to spasm of paraspinal muscles but can also be due to atlantoaxial dislocation requiring cervical collar and even traction.

questions.text: A patient presents to your OPD with hearing difficulty and scanty, foul-smelling discharge from the left ear. Otologic examination reveals the following finding. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of atticoantral type of CSOM and modified radical mastoidectomy is the treatment of choice here. 

Option A: Myringotomy is done in cases of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) and serous otitis media.

Options C and D: Medical management followed by myringoplasty or tympanoplasty once the ear is dry for 6 weeks without antibiotics is the treatment of choice for tubotympanic type of CSOM.

Related Pearl: Classification of CSOM

  Tubo-tympanic Attico-antral
Old name Safe type Unsafe ear
Recent name Mucosal variant Squamosal disease
Discharge

Profuse

Mucoid

Non-foul smelling

Non-blood stained

Scanty

Purulent

Foul-smelling

May be blood stained
Site Mostly in the pro-tympanum, i.e., part of middle ear around the Eustachian tube orifice Mostly involves the epi-tympanum/attic and involves the mastoid antrum via the aditus
Perforation Central (most common: Antero-inferior quadrant)

Attic (Pars flaccida) or

Marginal (most common: Postero-superior)
Granulations Uncommon Common
Polyp Pale, rare Fleshy red, common
Cholesteatoma Absent Present
Complications Rare Common
Treatment Medical/ surgical (Tympanoplasty) Always surgical (Mastoidectomy)

questions.text: What is the definitive treatment of intractable vertigo due to Meniere’s disease?
questions.solution:
The definitive treatment of intractable vertigo due to Ménière’s disease is labyrinthectomy. 

Labyrinthectomy involves uniform destruction of hearing and vestibular function. Ideal candidates have no functional hearing and have failed more conservative treatments, such as gentamicin injection. Despite this morbidity, labyrinthectomy has the highest rate of vertigo control (>95%), more than vestibular neurectomy (78-90%), and is considered the single definitive treatment.

The step-by-step management approach for Ménière's disease consists of dietary modifications and vestibular suppressants as the initial measures, followed by intratympanic gentamicin ablation, and finally, surgical intervention.

Primarily, the management of Menier's disease involves a sodium restricted diet and diuretics like acetazolamide (Option A). They are more useful for short-term control. 

Gentamicin (Option D) is a selective vestibulotoxic aminoglycoside antibiotic that is preferentially taken up by type I hair cells. It is opted for only if dietary modifications and vestibular suppressants have failed to control the symptoms. If used judiciously, hearing is preserved.

The options for surgical management include - Endolymphatic sac surgery, vestibular neurectomy, and labyrinthectomy. Endolymphatic sac surgery is currently declining in popularity due to lack of evidence of vertigo control. 

Vestibular neurectomy (Option C) refers to selective ablation of the vestibular nerve. Even though it is considered a hearing sparing surgery and carries comparable rates of vertigo control as labyrinthectomy, it is an intradural procedure and carries a greater risk of complications. Hearing loss will still progress as it would have in the natural course of illness.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding otosclerosis?

choices.text: Females are affected twice as often as males.
Stapedotomy should be avoided in children.
HRCT shows double ring sign in stapedial otosclerosis.
It may be associated with measles.

questions.solution:
HRCT shows the double-ring sign in cochlear otosclerosis, not in the stapedial type.

Otosclerosis affects females twice as often as males. But in India, otosclerosis seems to predominate in males.

Stapedotomy is contraindicated in children because recurrent eustachian tube dysfunction is common in them. This can displace the prosthesis or cause acute otitis media. 

Measles RNA has been found in otosclerotic foci implicating its possible role in pathogenesis.

questions.text: A woman is brought by her son to the ENT OPD due to hearing problems. He says that she always requests him to speak loud and whenever he speaks slightly louder, she tells him to stop shouting. Which of the following is the likely cause for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given symptom is indicative of a recruitment phenomenon and is seen in cochlear hearing loss (e.g. Ménière’s disease and presbycusis). It refers to abnormal growth of loudness. 

It is tested by ABLB (Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance) test. Lesser intensity sounds are heard louder in the normal ear. However, a greater intensity sound is heard equally, or even better in the abnormal ear. This is referred to as abnormal growth of loudness.

However, in the conductive hearing loss, a constant difference of intensity is maintained throughout.

Related Pearl: The differences between cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss

Test
Cochlear hearing loss
Retrocochlear hearing loss
Recruitment (ABLB test)
Present
Absent
*SISI score (Short Increment Sensitivity Index)
70 – 100%
0 – 20% 
Acoustic reflex threshold
Decreased due to recruitment
Increased
**Tone decay (nerve fatigue)
Absent
Present
Acoustic reflex decay (nerve fatigue)
Absent
Present
OAEs
Absent
Present
BERA (Best test)
Delayed wave-I, rest are normal
Only wave-I is present, rest are absent or affected
Speech discrimination score
  • Reduced
  • Roll over phenomenon absent
  • Very poor
  • Roll over phenomenon present

*Short Increment Sensitivity Index: A normal ear can’t differentiate short increments of sound but a recruiting ear can. SISI test is started sound 20db above the hearing threshold of the patient and 20 increments of 1db are given every 5 seconds. The total number of increments heard by the patient is recorded. SISI score of 70-100% is seen in cochlear deafness and of 0-20% in retrocochlear deafness.

** Threshold tone decay: It is a function of nerve fatigue. A Tone of 4000Hz is presented at 5dB above the patient’s threshold of hearing for 60 seconds. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. If loudness has to be increased by more than 30dB, it indicates retrocochlear hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about nasal T-cell lymphoma?

choices.text: It is also known as Stewart’s granulomas
It is a locally invasive tumor.
Surgery is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
T-cell lymphoma is treated by radiation when it is localised and by chemotherapy when it is disseminated.

The condition is also called as:

  • Non-healing midline granuloma 
  • Midline granulomas reticulosis 
  • Stewart’s granuloma 
  • Nasal T-cell lymphoma
  • Lethal midline granuloma

It is associated with EBV. Cells express T cell markers like CD56.

Nasal obstruction and epistaxis are the presenting features. Destruction of mid-facial structures may be caused by the local invasion.

Histologically, polymorphic lymphoid tissue with angiocentric and angioinvasive features are seen.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main arterial supply of palatine tonsils?

choices.text: Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery
Ascending palatine branch of facial artery

questions.solution:
The main arterial supply of tonsil is by the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.

Five arteries supply the tonsil:

  1. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (the main artery)
  2. Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery
  3. Ascending pharyngeal branch of the external carotid artery
  4. Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery
  5. Descending palatine branches of the maxillary artery

questions.text: A surgeon is to perform a mastoidectomy procedure for a patient with CSOM. He uses the following instrument during the procedure. What is the name of the given instrument?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mollison’s mastoid retractor. It is used in mastoidectomy procedures to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic.

Shown below is Jansen’s self-retaining mastoid retractor.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has been diagnosed with nasopharyngeal carcinoma which has spread to the sinus of Morgagni.  Which of the following structures is least likely to be affected due to the spread into this space?
questions.solution:
Descending pharyngeal artery does not pass through the sinus of Morgagni and hence least likely to be affected. All the other options are contents of the sinus of Morgagni. 

The sinus of Morgagni is a space between the base of the skull and the upper free border of the superior constrictor muscle.

The structures passing through the space are:

  • Eustachian tube
  • Levator veli palatini
  • Tensor veli palatini
  • Ascending palatine artery- branch of the facial artery

Trotter's triad or sinus of Morgagni syndrome is seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma which spreads laterally to involve the sinus of Morgagni. It is characterized by:

  • Conductive hearing loss
  • Ipsilateral immobility of the palate
  • Neuralgic pain

Related Pearl: Structures passing in the gaps between pharyngeal constrictors

Location Structures passing

Between the base of the skull and superior constrictor

(Sinus of Morgagni)

Mnemonic: PALE

Palatine branches of ascending pharyngeal artery

Ascending palatine artery

Levator veli palatini muscle

Eustachian tube 
Between superior and middle constrictors

Glossopharyngeal nerve

Stylopharyngeus muscle
Between middle and inferior constrictors

Internal laryngeal nerve

Superior laryngeal vessels
Below inferior constrictor

Recurrent laryngeal nerve

Inferior laryngeal vessels

questions.text: Which procedure is the following instrument not used in?
questions.solution:
The image shows Luc’s forceps. It is not used in FESS.

Luc’s forceps is used in:

  • Caldwell- Luc operation - to remove mucosa
  • Submucosal resection- to remove bone or cartilage
  • Polypectomy- to grasp and avulse polyps
  • To take a biopsy from the nose or throat

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis?
questions.solution:
The tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

The tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve. The glossopharyngeal nerve and the styloid process lie in relation to the lower part of the tonsillar fossa. Therefore, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve.

Causes of referred otalgia via the glossopharyngeal nerve include acute pharyngitis, tonsillitis, peritonsillar abscess, post-tonsillectomy, foreign bodies embedded in the base of the tongue or tonsillar area and an elongated styloid process (Eagle's syndrome).

The ear receives extensive sensory innervation via four cranial nerves (V, VII, IX, and X) and two spinal segments (C2 and C3).

The image below shows the anatomic relations of the tonsil and tonsillar bed:

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding septoplasty?

choices.text: It is done in cases of symptomatic nasal obstruction.
Mucoperiosteal flap is raised on both sides.

questions.solution:
Septoplasty is a conservative approach where mucoperichondrial/periosteal flap is generally raised only on one side. As much of the septal framework as possible is retained.

Submucous resection Septoplasty
Non-conservative procedure with extensive dissection of cartilage Conservative procedure
Not done in < 18 yrs Done children and adults
Killian’s incision is used Freer’s incision is used
Mucoperichondrial/periosteal flaps raised on both sides of the septum Flaps raised on only one side
More complications Fewer complications
Reoperation is difficult Reoperation is easier

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is classified using Ohngren’s classification?
questions.solution:
Ohngren’s classification is used for maxillary carcinoma.

An imaginary plane is drawn, extending between medial canthus of eye and the angle of mandible.

Ohngren's line(below image):

Growths situated above this plane (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those below it (infrastructural).

questions.text: You are an intern examining a patient with nasal obstruction and nasal discharge. The anterior rhinoscopy shows mulberry appearance of the inferior turbinate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The mulberry appearance of turbinate is seen in patients with hypertrophic rhinitis.

It is characterized by thickening of mucosa, submucosa, seromucinous glands, periosteum and bone.

Maximum changes are seen in the inferior turbinate.

questions.text: A patient is incidentally noted to have the following finding. It is also present on the other ear. Which of the following is the cause for such abnormality?

choices.text: Persistent opening of first branchial cleft

questions.solution:
The given image showing the presence of sinus seen between the tragus and crus of the helix is suggestive of the preauricular sinus. It is due to improper fusion of the auricular tubercle formed from the first and second arches. 

The preauricular sinus is apparent at birth and is usually bilateral. There may be occasional sebaceous discharge from the punctum. It does not regress spontaneously.

Related Pearl: Embryology of the ear

Structures of the ear Embryological origin
Auricle or pinna 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arch
External auditory meatus 1st pharyngeal arch
Tympanic membrane All 3 germ layers
Malleus and incus 1st pharyngeal arch
Stapes suprastructure 2nd pharyngeal arch
Stapes footplate and annular ligament Otic capsule
Tympanic cavity 1st pharyngeal pouch
Eustachian tube 1st pharyngeal pouch
Membranous labyrinth Otic vesicle
Semicircular canals and utricle Pars superior
Saccule and cochlea Pars inferior

questions.text: In a patient with an acoustic neuroma involving the sensory division of the facial nerve, the Hitzelberger sign was positive. What is the other name for this nerve?
questions.solution:
The sensory division of the facial nerve is also called the nerve of Wrisberg. The facial nerve is a mixed nerve having the motor and a sensory root.

Hitzelberger sign refers to hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall in acoustic neuroma due to the compression of the facial nerve.

Option A: Jacobson’s nerve - the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (9th cranial nerve). It is associated with glomus tympanicum.

Option B: Arnold’s nerve - the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (10th cranial nerve).

Option D: Herring’s nerve - the carotid sinus branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (9th cranial nerve).

questions.text: A patient having chronic otitis media with perforation of pars tensa is scheduled for myringoplasty to restore hearing. Which of the following is true regarding the techniques used here?

choices.text: In underlay technique, graft is placed medial to annulus
In underlay technique, graft is placed lateral to malleus
In overlay technique, graft is placed medial to annulus
In overlay technique, graft is placed lateral to malleus

questions.solution:
In the underlay technique, the graft is placed medial to the annulus. Whereas, in the overlay technique, the graft is placed lateral to the annulus. The graft is medial to malleus in both techniques.

Myringoplasty techniques are based on the relation of the graft with lamina propria of tympanic membrane remnants and fibrous annulus.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a pneumatic bone?
questions.solution:
The mandible is not a pneumatic bone.

Some bones of the skull, notably the mastoid process of the temporal bone and the paranasal sinuses of the frontal, maxilla, sphenoid and ethmoid bones, many of the internal cavities are filled with air, i.e. they are variably pneumatized.

The maxillae are the largest of the pneumatized bones of the midface. They contain the maxillary air sinuses and bear the upper teeth.

The mastoid consists of a bone cortex with a 'honeycomb' of air cells underneath.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is present in the oropharynx?
questions.solution:
Lingual tonsils are lymphoid tissues seen in the base of the tongue, hence a part of the oropharynx. 

Oropharynx includes:

  • Base of tongue
  • Palatine tonsils
  • Vallecula
  • Anterior and posterior pillars
  • Posterior pharyngeal wall

The pharyngeal end of the pharyngotympanic tube and fossa of Rosenmuller is present in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx.

The pyriform fossa is a part of the hypopharynx.

questions.text: A patient with otitis externa develops parotitis. You suspect that the infection has spread through the fissures of Santorini. Which of the following best describes this fissure?

choices.text: Connection between middle ear and pharynx
Connection between Inner ear and middle ear

questions.solution:
Fissures of Santorini are the two deficiencies in the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal. They provide a pathway for the spread of parotid or superficial mastoid infections to the canal or vice versa.

The bony canal also has a deficiency called the foramen of Huschke which acts as a pathway for the spread of infections and tumours to the deep lobe of the parotid.

questions.text: An ENT senior resident posted in a remote village comes across a patient in whom he suspects otosclerosis. Which of the following tests can be used if he wants to clinically confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gelle’s is a tuning fork test done to clinically confirm otosclerosis in the olden days.

It is based on the fact that in a normal ear if pressure is increased in the external ear the stapes footplate will get medialized and will stop conducting sound. But, in an ear with otosclerosis of the footplate, there will be no movements and the patient will continue to hear the sound. Thus, Gelle’s test is considered positive in normal persons and in those with sensorineural hearing loss. It is negative when the ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected.

Stenger’s test is done to rule out malingering.

Schwabach is a tuning fork test that compares the bone conduction of the patient with that of the examiner.

Rinne’s is a tuning fork test that compares bone conduction with air conduction.

questions.text: A known case of tubotympanic disease was taken up for surgery and on examining the middle ear, few chalky white deposits were found between the ossicles. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: Candidal infection of the middle ear

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tympanosclerosis. It is a sequela of long-standing middle ear disease where there are hyaline deposits within the middle ear, which calcify leading to impaired mobility of ossicles.

The common sites are the tympanic membrane, promontory, ossicles, joints, tendons, and oval and round windows.

When hyalinization and calcification involve only the tympanic membrane, it is known as myringosclerosis.

questions.text: A patient with persistent cervical lymphadenopathy now came with spontaneous epistaxis. Nasal endoscopy showed a mass arising from the fossa of Rosenmuller. Biopsy from the mass revealed a keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma. What is the treatment of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The treatment of choice is radiotherapy.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is extremely radiosensitive, hence treatment of local and regional disease is invariably radiotherapy. 

Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone. 

Stage III and IV are treated with radiotherapy and chemotherapy. Chemotherapy can be neoadjuvant, concurrent, or adjuvant to radiotherapy.

questions.text: While performing a parotidectomy, which of the following landmarks would you use to identify the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
Tragus is used as a surgical landmark to identify facial nerve in parotid surgery.

Surgical landmarks of the facial nerve for parotid surgery:

  • Tragal pointer -  triangular inferior portion of the tragus. The main trunk lies 1 cm deep to it.
  • Tympanomastoid suture - the main trunk lies 6-8 mm deep to it.
  • Styloid process - the nerve lies lateral to it
  • Posterior belly of digastric attachment at the digastric groove - the nerve can be found emerging from the stylomastoid foramen under the muscle but lateral to the styloid process.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common benign tumor of the middle ear?
questions.solution: Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear and is so-named because of its origin from the glomus bodies.

questions.text: A boxer is wheeled into the ER with complaints of seeing double after having suffered a severe blow to his face during a match. On examination, there is a flattening of malar prominence, trismus and a step deformity of the infraorbital margin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of diplopia, flat malar prominence, trismus, and step deformity in the infraorbital margin is suggestive of fracture of zygoma or tripod fracture.

Zygoma is the second most frequently fractured bone in the face. The zygoma fracture is separated at its three processes - the zygomaticofrontal suture, infraorbital margin, and the zygomaticotemporal suture. It has the following clinical features:

  • Flattening of malar prominence. 
  • Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process. 
  • Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve. 
  • Step deformity of infraorbital margin.
  • Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament. 
  • Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause diplopia. 
  • Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing.

The following x-ray shows a right-sided zygoma fracture:

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in a patient who presents with a painful ear swelling as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of painful, erythematous ear swelling is suggestive of perichondritis.

The most common cause is trauma either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or non-iatrogenic (laceration, hematoma). It can be due to the extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of the meatus. The most common organism responsible is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

The image given below shows a patient with a cauliflower ear deformity. It is also known as perichondrial hematoma or wrestler's ear. It is usually caused by repeated episodes of trauma.

 

Chondrodermatitis chronica helicis is a small, nodular, tender, chronic inflammatory lesion occurring on the helix of the ear. It is shown in the image below. 

 

Otitis externa, also called swimmer's ear, is the inflammation of the ear canal. It has the following appearance:

Related Pearl: Eponyms of the ear

Eponym

Description

Boxer’s/ Cauliflower ear

Organized hematoma of pinna

Surfer’s ear

Exostosis

Swimmer’s ear

Diffuse otitis externa

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the structure marked as A?

choices.text: It is part of the Waldeyer's ring
Hypertrophies up to the age of 6 years and starts to regress from puberty
It is surrounded by a capsule

questions.solution:
The structure marked A is the adenoids. It is not surrounded by a capsule.

Adenoids are comprised of vertical ridges of lymphoid tissues separated by deep clefts. They form the superior aspect of Waldeyer's ring. They have no crypts and no capsule, unlike palatine tonsils which have both.

It is present at birth, enlarges up to the age of 6 years, and then starts regressing from puberty. It completely disappears by the age of 20 years.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing direct laryngoscopy, subglottic stenosis is noted. Which grading system will you use to report the extent of the stenosis?
questions.solution:
Myer Cotton’s grading is used for subglottic stenosis.

It is the abnormal thickening of cricoid/fibrous tissue proliferation below cords. It causes the airway to narrow and presents with dyspnea, biphasic stridor and a normal cry. 

Diagnosis:

  • In full-term infants, subglottic diameter <4mm.
  • In premature infants, subglottic diameter <3mm.

The Myer Cotton’s grading system allows to stratify the stenosis and plan for treatment:

  • Grade 1: <50% stenosis
  • Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis
  • Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis
  • Grade 4: No lumen detected

Other options

  • Option A - Hyams grading is a predictive tool used in olfactory neuroblastoma.
  • Option B - House Brackmann grading is used as a facial nerve grading system.
  • Option D - Modified mallampati classification is used to assess difficult airway

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to the ENT OPD with complaints of difficulty in hearing. A pure tone audiometry test is performed and the result is given below. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
The given pure tone audiometry is suggestive of right-sided sensorineural deafness.

Interpretation of the result:

  • Red indicates the right ear.
  • O indicates air conduction(AC). The threshold here is >15 dB indicating abnormal AC.
  • < indicates bone conduction(BC). The threshold is >25 dB indicating abnormal BC.
  • Both AC and BC are abnormal which indicates a sensorineural hearing loss.
  • There is no air-bone gap.
  • Hence, it is right side sensorineural hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: A 5 year old with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice over three months and respiratory distress for 2 weeks. Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests that the child is suffering from Respiratory papillomatosis.

Respiratory papillomatosis (juvenile papillomatosis )

  • It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is caused by HPV 6 and 11. 
  • Involves supraglottic and glottic regions of larynx .
  • C/F
    • Age 3–5 years
    • Hoarseness or aphonia
    • Respiratory difficulty
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. 
  • Treatment consists of microlaryngoscopy and CO2 laser Excision.

Other options:

  • Options A) Croup (acute laryngotracheobronchitis) and D) Acute epiglottitis are acute conditions and therefore ruled out.
  • Option C) Vocal Nodule: They appear symmetrically on the free edge of vocal cord, at the junction of anterior one-third, with the posterior two thirds due to trauma. Present only with hoarseness.

questions.text: Which of the following complications would you not expect to see in a patient diagnosed with diphtheria?
questions.solution:
Hard palate paralysis is not seen in diphtheria.

The exotoxin produced by C. diphtheriae is toxic to the heart and nerves. It causes:

  • Myocarditis
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Acute circulatory failure

Neurological complications include paralysis of the soft-palate, diaphragm, and ocular muscles. In the larynx, the diphtheric membrane may cause airway obstruction.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with unilateral nasal obstruction. To check for patency of the nasal valve, a Cottle test is performed. In which of the following cases is the test positive?
questions.solution:
Cottle test is positive in patients with a deviated nasal septum. It is used to assess the patency of the nasal valve and when positive, it indicates the abnormality in the vestibular component of the nasal valve.

In this test, the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. If the nasal airway improves and the obstruction is relieved on the test side, the test is positive and indicates the surgery will be useful and the patient can be taken up for surgery.

The nasal valve area is the narrowest portion of the nasal passage. It is bounded medially by the nasal septum, superiorly and laterally by the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage, inferiorly by the floor of the piriform aperture and the nasal valve is the specific slit-like segment between the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage and the septum.

Conditions with a positive Cottle test:

  • Deviated nasal septum
  • Collapsed nasal valve - causes snoring and sleep apnoea
  • Valve stenosis

The below image depicts Cottle's test

The deviated nasal septum (DNS) may be caused by two main factors, trauma or developmental errors in addition to being dependent on racial and hereditary factors. Patients present with nasal obstruction, headache, sinusitis, and epistaxis and may manifest an external deformity as well.

Anatomically, DNS can be of various types

  • Anterior dislocation or the septal cartilage into one of the chambers
  • C-shaped deformity: the chamber on the concave side of the nasal septum will be wider and show compensatory hypertrophy of turbinates
  • S-shaped deformity: may cause bilateral nasal obstruction
  • Spur: a shelf-like projection often found at the junction of bone and cartilage
  • Thickening: thickening of a septum due to an organised hematoma may also cause obstruction

Treatment of DNS depends on the severity of symptoms. If asymptomatic, no treatment is required. When DNS causes a mechanical obstruction, submucosal resection or septoplasty (more conservative) may be done.

Other options:

Epistaxis refers to bleeding into the nasal cavity and most commonly occurs in the little's area in the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum. Cottle test to relieve nasal obstruction has no role here. Trotter's method is used as a first aid to arrest bleeding from the little's area.

Atrophic rhinitis refers to chronic inflammation of the nose with atrophy of nasal mucosa. The patients may present with nasal obstruction due to the crusting filling the roomy nasal cavity. Removal of the crust may relieve the obstruction but has the risk of bleeding.

The nasal polyp occurs due to edematous nasal mucosa. It can be an antrochoanal polyp arising from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum or an ethmoidal polyp arising from the middle meatus in the lateral wall of the nose. These polyps appear as globular mass and can be differentiated from turbinate hypertrophy by a probe test. Nasal obstruction resulting from polyps get resolved by conservative or surgical management.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about quinsy is false?

choices.text: Collection of pus between the capsule of tonsil and superior constrictor
Presents with odynophagia and drooling of saliva

questions.solution:
Peritonsillar abscess or quinsy is usually unilateral. 

 

It is a collection of pus in the peritonsillar space which lies between the capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle.

Usually, it is unilateral though occasionally bilateral abscesses are recorded.

It presents with marked odynophagia such that the patient cannot even swallow his saliva which dribbles from the angle of his mouth. The patient is usually dehydrated.

Muffled and thick speech, often called hot potato voice.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about spasmodic dysphonia?

choices.text: May be associated with other dystonias
Abductor type produces breathy voice and adductor type produces strangulated voice
Botulinum toxin is used in treatment

questions.solution:
Spasmodic dysphonia is not only a local laryngeal disorder. It is associated with many neurological conditions too.

There are 2 types of spasmodic dysphonia:

Adductor dysphonia

  • The adductor muscles of the larynx go into spasm causing vocal cords to go into adduction. The voice becomes strained/strangled. 
  • Treatment consists of botulinum toxin injections in the thyroarytenoid muscles on one or both sides to relieve the spasm.

Abductor dysphonia

  • It is due to the spasm of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle and thus the glottis is kept open.
  • The patient gets a breathy voice or breathy breaks in voice.

Treatment consists of botulinum toxin injections in posterior cricoarytenoid muscles. Patients who do not respond to toxin injection can be treated by type 1 thyroplasty or fat injection.

questions.text: What is the most commonly affected part in otosclerosis?
questions.solution: The most commonly affected part in the stapedial type of otosclerosis is the fissula ante fenestrum lying in front of the oval window.

questions.text: What type of tympanogram would you expect to see in a patient with serous otitis media?
questions.solution:
B-type tympanogram is expected in a case of serous otitis media.

Here, compliance decreases i.e., mobility of tympanic membrane is restricted due to the effusion, usually secondary to negative middle ear pressure (eustachian tube obstruction). This results in a B-type tympanogram. 

Hearing tests suggestive of conductive hearing loss as seen in serous otitis media:

  • Rinne negative (BC>AC).
  • Weber - lateralized towards the worse ear
  • Audiogram - AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
  • Impedance audiometry - flat curve (reduced compliance, shift to the negative side)

Note: Tympanograph is Flat when there is Fluid in the middle ear.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common malignant tumor of the nasal cavity?
questions.solution: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the nasal cavity, seen in about 80% of cases.

questions.text: An elderly woman with a history of otosclerosis has now come with worsening deafness. She attained menopause 1 year ago. What would be the most likely report if impedance audiometry was done for her?

choices.text: Ad graph with increased stapedial reflex
As graph with loss of stapedial reflex
As graph with increased stapedial reflex

questions.solution:
The above case is suggestive of a long-standing case of otosclerosis and impedance audiometry will show As graph and loss of stapedial reflex as a result of fixation of ossicles.

Impedance audiometer measures 2 parameters in the middle ear:

  • Tympanogram - Type As is seen in otosclerosis due to decreased compliance at or near ambient air pressure
  • Stapedial reflex - Stapedial reflex is lost due to immobile ossicles.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman suffering from iron deficiency anemia presents to you with difficulty in swallowing. On examination, glossitis and cheilitis are observed. There are oesophageal webs seen on direct laryngoscopy.  Which of the following is the most common site for carcinoma to develop in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of a diagnosis of Plummer-Vinson syndrome. The post-cricoid region is a common site for carcinoma in women suffering from Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Plummer-Vinson syndrome/ Patterson Kelly Brown syndrome is a condition that can occur in people with long-term (chronic) iron deficiency anemia. The triad seen in these patients:

  • Post cricoid webs
  • Glossitis
  • Angular cheilitis

Post cricoid region is the part of the anterior wall of the laryngopharynx between the upper and lower borders of the cricoid lamina.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about malignant otitis externa?

choices.text: It is due to pseudomonas infection
Technetium 99 bone scan is used for follow up
Facial nerve is the most common affected nerve

questions.solution:
Technetium 99 bone scan remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to follow up response to treatment. It is particularly useful when the clinical suspicion for malignant otitis externa is high but the CT scan is negative.

Features of malignant otitis externa:

  • Pseudomonas infection in the elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs.
  • Excruciating pain, profuse discharge & granulations on the floor of the external auditory canal.
  • Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection.
  • Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.
  • Facial paralysis is the most common nerve palsy seen.
  • Mitotic figures will be normal since it is an infective and not a malignant condition.
  • Gallium-67 is more useful in the follow-up of the patient.

questions.text: You are a junior resident in the ENT department. A patient presents to you with pulsatile tinnitus. Which of the following will be your first differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Glomus tumour will be your first differential diagnosis. Tinnitus in glomus tumors is:

  • Pulsatile
  • Of swishing character
  • Synchronous with pulse and
  • Can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure.

questions.text: In a patient with findings as shown in the image, which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: It is known as elephantiasis of the nose
It is seen in long standing cases of acne rosacea
It is commonly seen in middle aged women
It is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands

questions.solution:
The given image is diagnostic of rhinophyma. It is commonly seen in men past middle age.

Rhinophyma or potato tumour or elephantiasis of nose is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands. It is usually associated with long-standing cases of acne rosacea. Mostly seen at the tip of the nose and causes unsightly appearance and obstruction to breathing and vision. 

Treatment: Debulk of the tumor with carbon dioxide laser and the area is allowed to re-epithelialize. Sometimes the tumor is completely excised and skin is grafted over the raw area.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions would you expect to observe the light-house effect?
questions.solution:
The light-house effect is seen in acute mastoiditis, which is a complication of otitis media. This effect is described as a pulsatile mucopurulent or purulent discharge, coming through a central pin-hole perforation of pars tensa. This suggests a reservoir of infection in the mastoid and middle ear.

Note: Otoscopic signs in intratympanic glomus tumors include:

  • Red reflex through an intact tympanic membrane
  • Pulsation sign or Brown sign - when ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel’s speculum, the tumor pulsates vigorously and then blanches

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication of high tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
Carcinoma larynx is an indication of high tracheostomy.

Types of tracheostomy:

 

High

Mid(Normal)

Low

Level

1st tracheal ring

2/3rd tracheal ring

3/4th tracheal ring

Indications

Carcinoma larynx

Routine indications: Foreign body,Head injury resulting in unconsciousness,Laryngeal diphtheria, Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

Laryngo-tracheal stenosis, Crush injury to larynx.

 

 

The only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx because in such cases, total larynx anyway would ultimately be removed and a fresh tracheostome made in a clean area lower down.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common symptoms that acoustic neuroma presents with?
questions.solution:
Progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), often accompanied by tinnitus, is the presenting symptom in the majority of cases.

Early symptoms of acoustic neuroma:

  • Progressive unilateral SNHL
  • Gross inability to understand speech out of proportion to the PTA average
  • Tinnitus
  • Unsteadiness and imbalance

The involvement of other cranial nerves leads to other deficits.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma?
questions.solution:
The most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma is Habermann's theory. It proposes that the skin of the external auditory meatus grows or migrates into the middle ear through the posterosuperior marginal perforation or attic perforation forming cholesteatoma.

Related Pearl: Classification and theories for origin of cholesteatoma

Classification:

Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at birth.

Primary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars flaccida. 

Secondary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars tensa.

Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma is defined as that which occurs behind a normal-appearing tympanic membrane as the result of implantation of an antecedent middle ear inflammation.

 
Type
Theory
Description
Congenital Cholesteatoma
Congenital cell rests
The presence of congenital epithelial cell rests within the middle ear cleft/ temporal bone.
Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Wittmaack’s theory of retraction pockets
Negative middle ear pressure leads to the formation of retraction pockets (usually in the posterosuperior part of pars tensa and the pars flaccida) which accumulates keratin debris.
Ruedi’s theory of basal cell hyperplasia
The basal cell layer of the germinal layer of skin proliferates in response to infection & other stimuli.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (Otitis media with effusion) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.
Secondary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Habermann’s theory of epithelial invasion
Marginal perforation leads to ingrowth of squamous epithelium of the meatus or outer surface of the tympanic membrane into middle ear.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (ASOM/CSOM) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.

ASOM: Acute suppurative otitis media; CSOM: Chronic suppurative otitis media.

questions.text: What is the other name for Shrapnell’s membrane?
questions.solution:
Pars flaccida is also known as Shrapnell’s membrane.

Pars flaccida is situated above the lateral process of malleus between the notch of Rivinus and the anterior and posterior mallear folds.

Related Pearl: Tympanic membrane

Parts of the tympanic membrane

Pars Tensa
Pars Flaccida
Taut
Loose
Middle fibrous layer is well organized
Middle fibrous layer is not well organized
Contains annulus tympanicus
 Also called Shrapnell’s membrane
Transmits sound
Does not transmit sound

Layers of the tympanic membrane

  Outer Middle Inner
Layer Epithelium Fibrous Mucosa
Continuous with Skin of EAC - Middle ear mucosa
Derived from Ectoderm Mesoderm Endoderm
Made of - Circular, radial & parabolic fibers -

questions.text: On oral examination of a patient with recurrent upper respiratory tract infection, you notice that the Waldeyer’s group of lymph nodes is enlarged. Which of the following is not included in Waldeyer’s group of lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
The submandibular group of lymph nodes is not included as a part of Waldeyer’s ring.

Scattered throughout the pharynx in its subepithelial layer is the lymphoid tissue which is aggregated at places to form masses, collectively called Waldeyer’s ring.
The masses are:

  • Adenoids or nasopharyngeal tonsils
  • Palatine tonsils or simply tonsils
  • Lingual tonsils
  • Tubal tonsils
  • Lateral pharyngeal bands
  • Nodules in the posterior pharyngeal wall

questions.text: Which of the following supplies the tensor veli palatini muscle?
questions.solution:
The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve supplies the tensor veli palatini which opens the Eustachian tube.

Muscles of the Eustachian tube:

Muscle

Nerve supply

Action

Tensor veli palatine/ Dilator tubae

Mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve

Opens the tube

Levator veli palatine

Pharyngeal plexus 

Opens & lifts the tube

Salpingopharyngeus

Pharyngeal plexus 

Opens the tube

Sensory & parasympathetic supply to ET: Glossopharyngeal Nerve

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation to confirm acoustic neuroma?
questions.solution:
MRI with gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acoustic neuroma.

It is superior to a CT scan. Intracanalicular tumors measuring even a few millimeters can be easily diagnosed by this method.

questions.text: In a patient with suspected CSF rhinorrhea, the presence of which of the following in the nasal discharge will confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presence of β 2 transferrin protein in the nasal discharge confirms the presence of CSF in the specimen.

β 2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for CSF. It is secreted by meninges and choroid plexus.

Since it is absent in nasal secretions it helps to differentiate CSF from nasal secretions. It is also present in aqueous humor and perilymph.

Another method is glucose testing by oxidase peroxidase or biochemical estimation. CSF glucose is 60% of blood glucose whereas it is <10mg/dl in nasal secretions. It is not reliable in associated meningitis (reduced levels giving false-negative results) and when CSF is mixed with blood.

questions.text: While performing syringing for a patient with impacted wax, along which wall of the meatus would you direct the jet of water?
questions.solution:
During syringing, the pinna is pulled upwards and backward and the water jet is directed along the posterosuperior wall of the meatus. This is preferred because of two anatomical reasons:

  1. On maneuvering the pinna to bring the EAC into a straight configuration, the posterior wall is straighter and easily accessible than the anterior wall.
  2. The posteroinferior wall of EAC is supplied by the vagus. Direct stimulation of this can lead to sudden cardiac arrest.

Complications of syringing:

  • Vertigo– caloric stimulation of lateral semicircular canal if water is too hot or too cold
  • Rupture of the tympanic membrane
  • Reactivation of quiescent otitis media, if there is pre-existing perforation

Contraindications for syringing:

  • Presence of ear infection, tympanic membrane perforation
  • Presence of grommet or history of ear surgery

questions.text: A newborn developed respiratory distress immediately after delivery. The paediatrician was unable to pass the nasogastric tube through both the nares. Which of the following statements is false about the above diagnosis?

choices.text: It is due to persistence of bucconasal membrane
Can be associated with CHARGE syndrome.
Bony obstruction is more common than membranous obstruction
Immediate tracheostomy to be done to maintain the airway.

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of bilateral choanal atresia and immediate tracheostomy is not indicated.

Simply securing a feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway and forces the infant to breathe through the mouth. This is known as McGovern’s technique and obviates the need for tracheostomy.

Related Pearl: Choanal atresia

It is due to the persistence of bucconasal membrane which separates primitive oropharynx from the primitive nasopharynx. It has the following features:

  • Bony obstruction is more common than membranous
  • Unilateral > bilateral
  • Unilateral cases may be asymptomatic and present in adult life
  • Bilateral cases are life-threatening and present with respiratory distress
  • Associated with CHARGE syndrome
    • C- Coloboma of the eye
    • H- Heart defects
    • A- Atresia of choana
    • R- Retarded growth and development
    • G- Genital anomalies
    • E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss.

CT scan is the investigation of choice

Image: Membranous, bilateral choanal atresia in a newborn

Immediate management involves placing a feeding nipple with a large hole at the mouth to force the baby to mouth-breathe - McGoverns technique.

Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by a trans-nasal or trans-palatal approach.

questions.text: A patient is referred to the ENT OPD with left-sided nasal obstruction, disfigurement of the face, and displacement of his left eye. Imaging of paranasal sinuses shows an ill-defined expanding lesion with ground glass appearance in the maxillary sinus. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is fibrous dysplasia. A ground-glass appearance in CT or x-ray is characteristic of fibrous dysplasia.

In fibrous dysplasia, bone is replaced by fibrous tissue. The most common site is the maxillary sinus, followed by the ethmoid and frontal sinuses. 

It can present with disfigurement of the face, nasal obstruction, and displacement of the eye.

The x-ray image below shows a ground-glass appearance present in the left maxillary sinus due to fibrous dysplasia. The lesion is not well demarcated and merges with the surrounding area. There is orbital displacement on the left side.

questions.text: Which of the following deformity is likely to be seen in a patient with juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma?
questions.solution:
Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma when spreads to the orbit, lead to proptosis and broadening of the nasal bridge, giving rise to frog-face deformity.

Option A: Gorilla-like facies are seen in acromegaly.

Option C: Bird-like facies are seen in the Pierre-Robin sequence.

Option D: Lion-like facies are seen in Paget's disease of bone when craniofacial bones are involved.

questions.text: You are the second-year ENT resident performing tonsillectomy in a patient with chronic tonsillitis. While creating a dissection plane between the capsule and the bed of the tonsil, you accidentally deepened the incision, injuring the tonsillar bed. Which of the following structures is least likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The lateral pterygoid muscle is not related to the bed of the tonsil and is the least likely structure to be injured in this scenario.

The bed of the tonsil is formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles.

The lower fossa is related to:

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve
  • The styloid process

Outside the superior constrictor, the tonsil is related to:

  • The facial artery
  • Submandibular salivary gland
  • Posterior belly of the digastric muscle
  • Medial pterygoid muscle
  • The angle of the mandible

questions.text: You are the ENT resident examining a patient in the wards. On asking him to swallow you notice the larynx moves upwards. Which of the following muscles is not responsible for this movement?
questions.solution:
The sternohyoid is not responsible for upward movement (elevation). It is a depressor of the larynx.

The extrinsic muscles of the larynx can be elevators or depressors.

Elevators:

Primary elevators act directly as they are attached to the thyroid cartilage and include

  • Stylopharyngeus
  • Salpingopharyngeus
  • Palatopharyngeus
  • Thyrohyoid

Secondary elevators act indirectly as they are attached to the hyoid bone and include

  • Mylohyoid (main)
  • Digastric
  • Stylohyoid
  • Geniohyoid

Depressors:

  • Sternohyoid
  • Sternothyroid
  • Omohyoid

Easy to remember: Check the other attachment(non-laryngeal side). If it's above the level of the hyoid, the muscle is an elevator. If it's below the level of the hyoid, it’s a depressor.

questions.text: A teenage boy suffered trauma to his left eye while playing cricket. He is rushed to the ER in severe pain. His X-ray appears as below. What is the characteristic sign noted?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the tear-drop sign. It is seen in orbital floor or blow-out fractures when the orbital contents herniate into the maxillary antrum.

Option B: Phelp’s sign is seen in CT scan in glomus jugulare tumor. It is the erosion of the normal crest of bone between the carotid canal and jugular foramen.

Options C and D: Antral and Holman Miller signs are the same. It is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus and is pathognomonic of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the ENT OPD with a swelling on the right side of his neck. The swelling moves with deglutition. On examination, the swelling is compressible and there is a gurgling sound heard on compression. What is his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
On compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling/hissing sound known as Bryce’s sign. The given clinical picture with a positive Bryce sign is suggestive of laryngocele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cavity within the larynx developing from the saccule. The patient presents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible.

Options A: Branchial cleft cysts does not move with deglutition.

Option C: Cystic hygroma does not move with deglutition and usually presents before 2 years.

Option D: Thyroglossal cyst presents as a midline swelling.

questions.text: In a stapedectomy specimen of a patient with otosclerosis, a pathologist noted that a few areas of the otic capsule appeared more basophilic than normal. What is this appearance called?
questions.solution:
The blue mantle sign of Manasseh is a histopathological finding seen in otosclerosis.

On histopathological examination of an otosclerotic foci, the osteoblasts and osteoclasts lie in an abundance of cement substance, which stains blue with hematoxylin and eosin stain.

Option B - Blue dot sign is seen in the torsion of the testicular appendage.

Blue cement sign and islets in ocean sign do not exist.

questions.text: What is the lever ratio of the ear ossicles?
questions.solution:
The lever ratio of the ear ossicles is 1.3:1.

The handle of the malleus is 1.3 times longer than the long process of the incus, providing a mechanical advantage of 1.3.

questions.text: A concerned mother brought her toddler to the ER with complaints of noisy breathing and the child refusing to feed. On examination, the child has adenoid facies and there is a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall lateral to the midline. Which of the following is a false statement regarding the disease described above?

choices.text: Suppuration of nodes of Rouvier can cause the above condition
Caries of the cervical spine is the most common cause
In adults similar condition may result from penetrating injury of the cervical esophagus
Torticollis is one of the symptoms.

questions.solution:
The above clinical condition is suggestive of acute retropharyngeal abscess whereas caries of the cervical spine results in a chronic retropharyngeal abscess.

Acute retropharyngeal abscess is commonly seen in children below 3 years. It is the result of suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to infection in the adenoids, nasopharynx, posterior nasal sinuses, or nasal cavity.

In adults, it may result from penetrating injury of the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical esophagus.

Clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include

  • Dysphagia and difficulty in breathing - as the abscess obstructs the air and food passages. 
  • Stridor and croupy cough 
  • Torticollis - the neck becomes stiff and the head is kept extended. 
  • A bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall, usually seen on one side of the midline. 

Chronic retropharyngeal abscess is the result of

  • Caries of the cervical spine
  • Tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to tuberculosis of deep cervical nodes.

questions.text: Otoscopic image of a patient with a history of repeated middle ear infections is shown below. Which one of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is also known as epidermosis

questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of a large mass of white keratin debris in the left upper quadrant of the left tympanic membrane. This along with clinical scenario is suggestive of cholesteatoma which is also known as epidermosis or keratoma

Cholesteatoma is the presence of stratified squamous epithelium in middle ear where it is not usually present, i.e., skin in wrong place.

A central white mass, consisting of keratin debris is produced by the matrix. For this reason, it has also been named epidermosis or keratoma.

The term cholesteatoma is a misnomer because it neither contains cholesterol crystals nor it is a tumor to merit the suffix “oma.”

questions.text: Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis for a patient with suspected Ménière’s disease?
questions.solution:
CSOM is a middle ear disease with symptoms of ear discharge and is not a differential for Ménière’s.

Ménière’s is a cochlear pathology with symptoms of vertigo, hearing loss & tinnitus.

Differentials of Ménière’s disease:

  • Vestibular neuronitis
  • BPPV
  • Cervical spondylosis
  • Acoustic tumours
  • Vertebrobasilar insufficiency
  • Labyrinthitis
  • Perilymph fistula
  • Migraine induced vertigo

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the eustachian tube?

choices.text: Outer 1/3rd is bony and inner 2/3rd is cartilaginous

questions.solution:
The eustachian tube also called the auditory or pharyngotympanic tube connects the nasopharynx with the tympanic cavity.

It is 36 mm long in adults and is divided into two parts:

  • Bony part - forms the outer one-third of the tube as it is located near the middle ear and is 12 mm in size.
  • Fibrocartilaginous part - forms the inner two-third as it is located near the nasopharynx and is 24 mm in size.

In the middle ear it opens in the anterior wall and in the nasopharynx it opens 1-1.25 cm posterior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate.

questions.text: Saccule in larynx is an extension of_____
questions.solution:
The saccule of the larynx is an extension of the ventricle.

The deep elliptical space present between vestibular and vocal folds is known as the ventricle or sinus of the larynx. The saccule is a diverticulum of mucous membrane that arises from the anterior part of this ventricular cavity. It extends upwards between vestibular folds and the lamina of the thyroid. When the saccule is abnormally enlarged and distended, it may form an air-containing sac in the neck known as a laryngocele.

Other options:

Options A and B: Two potential spaces within the larynx provide an avenue for the spread of tumors and are continuous with each other.

The pre-epiglottic space of Boyer is bounded:

  • Superiorly by the hyoepiglottic ligament
  • Anteriorly by the thyroid and thyrohyoid membrane
  • Posteromedially by the infrahyoid epiglottis and quadrangular membrane.

The paraglottic space is bounded:

  • Laterally by thyroid
  • Medially by ventricle and quadrangular membrane
  • Inferomedially by conus elasticus
  • Posteriorly by pyriform sinus.

Option C: Reinke's space lies under the epithelium of vocal cords. It has the following boundaries :

  • Superior and inferiorly by arcuate lines
  • Anteriorly by anterior commissure
  • Posteriorly by vocal process of arytenoid

questions.text: A patient with a family history of nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with nasal discharge and a painless lump in the upper neck. On posterior rhinoscopy, where will you most commonly expect to find a mass originating from?
questions.solution: The most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller.

questions.text: Which of the following cases cannot be posted for an elective tonsillectomy?

choices.text: A young adult with chronic tonsillitis refractory to treatment
A patient with unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspected malignancy
A middle-aged man with recurrent quinsy

questions.solution:
Acute tonsillitis is a contraindication for tonsillectomy and hence, cannot be posted for elective surgery.

Acute tonsillitis or any upper respiratory tract infection is a contraindication for tonsillectomy since there is an increased chance of hemorrhage and sepsis.

Indications of tonsillectomy are:

  • Recurrent episodes of acute tonsillitis – most common indication
    Seven or more episodes in 1 year, or
    Five episodes per year for 2 years, or
    Three episodes per year for 3 years, or
    Two weeks or more of lost school or work in 1 year
  • Febrile seizures due to fever in tonsillitis
  • Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) - recurrent episodes in adults and a single episode in children
  • Hypertrophy of tonsils causing airway obstruction, difficulty in deglutition, interference with speech
  • Unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspicion of malignancy
  • Chronic tonsillitis with bad taste or halitosis which is unresponsive to medical treatment (relative indication)
